page.title: 09LOCAL HISTORY 3
page.content: {Plucks Gutter}was a major ferry point after the inning of the marsh had reduced the Wantsum to a river. By 1800 the Stour here was only about 100 feet across, with a pub the{"Dog and {Duck"}as the ferry point. This building still stands as a cottage. Oral tradition has it that the{Bridge was built by an inkeeper who saw possibilities for "carriage trade". He built a new Dog and Duck in a position more suited to the bridge and added extensive stables. This ideal of Edwardian riverside picnics washed down with Kentish Ale, boating,and towpath strolls did not last. Within a few years the{motor car}had made the stables redundant. The convenience of the new bridge made for fast through traffic and nobody stopped. It took the caravan boom to regenerate the pub.
